edu.spa.ftclib.internal.drivetrain

Class HolonomicFourWheelDrivetrain

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.spa.ftclib.internal.drivetrain.Drivetrain
      • edu.spa.ftclib.internal.drivetrain.HolonomicFourWheelDrivetrain
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Holonomic, Positionable, Rotatable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MecanumDrivetrain, OmniwheelDrivetrain

    public abstract class HolonomicFourWheelDrivetrain
extends Drivetrain
implements Holonomic, Rotatable, Positionable
    Created by Gabriel on 2017-12-27. A holonomic drivetrain with four wheels. MecanumDrivetrain and OmniwheelDrivetrain extend this; we wrote this because most of that code is very similar.

    • Field Summary

    • Constructor Detail

      • HolonomicFourWheelDrivetrain

        public HolonomicFourWheelDrivetrain(DcMotor[] motors,
                                    double[] wheelAngles)
        Parameters:
        motors - The array of motors included in the drivetrain
        wheelAngles - A list of four angles corresponding to each wheel related to wheel and drivetrain geometry; these should be defined by the subclass and are passed to calculateWheelCoefficient(double, double) (which also must be defined by the subclass)

        Sets the drivetrain's angular (rotational) velocity.
        Specified by:
        setRotation in interface Rotatable
        Parameters:
        rotation - The velocity that you want to rotate the robot at, between -1 (full power clockwise) and 1 (full power counterclockwise) — 0 for no rotation

        Parameters:

      • updatePosition

        public void updatePosition()
        Empty — we use the built-in, automatic PID controller to move the motors, so there's nothing to update here.
        Specified by:
        updatePosition in interface Positionable

      • isPositioning

        public boolean isPositioning()
        Use this as a loop condition (with #updatePosition in the loop body) if you want to move to a specific position and then move on to other code. If the drivetrain never seems to stop positioning, use {@link com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.DcMotorEx#setTargetPositionTolerance} on each of your motors to make them less perfectionistic.
        Specified by:
        isPositioning in interface Positionable
        Returns:
        Whether or not the drivetrain is still moving towards the target position

      • finishPositioning

        public void finishPositioning()
        Resets encoders and changes the RunModes to what they were before

        Specified by:

      • getTicksPerUnit

        public double getTicksPerUnit()
        Depending on the encoder type, the number of ticks per rotation can vary. This method uses motor configuration data to calculate that number.
        Specified by:
        getTicksPerUnit in interface Positionable
        Returns:
        the number of encoder ticks per rotation
